qas.question: What was the Sun's headline on 4 May 1982?
Why did The Sun change the wording of the headline?

answers.text: the extent of Argentinian casualties became known

qas.question: Which reporter saw copies of The Sun being thrown into the ocean?
What ship were copies of The Sun thrown from?

context: One of the paper's best known front pages, published on 4 May 1982, commemorated the torpedoing of the Argentine ship <a1_0>the General Belgrano<a1_0/> by running the story under the headline <a0_0>"GOTCHA"<a0_0/>. At MacKenzie's insistence, and against the wishes of Murdoch (the mogul was present because almost all the journalists were on strike), the headline was changed for later editions after <a2_0>the extent of Argentinian casualties became known<a2_0/>. <a3_0>John Shirley<a3_0/>, a reporter for The Sunday Times, witnessed copies of this edition of The Sun being thrown overboard by sailors and marines on <a4_0>HMS Fearless<a4_0/>.
